body:
How and where did performance change? I would like to see a reproduction to make sure I understand. Use of generic types as root value is discouraged; and type resolution should rarely be a performance bottleneck, esp. so for generic types. So I would want to make sure that this isn't masking some other issue.
Would it be possible to add a link to use case, or sample code, or just simplified class definition + usage to show what is the problem case?

As to backporting, branch 2.6 is closed, so no new full releases are planned. So it is unlikely change would be ported.

With 2.7 I do have concerns about change that could fundamentally break things in various places -- caching can be great for performance, but may also introduce very subtle bugs, especially if bound type parameters accidentally clash (that is, earlier resolution with certain bindings get cached and used for slightly different bindings). But if fix was deemed safe enough, that would be doable.

2.8.0 is to be released within a week so that would, in general, be the most likely addition point.

Ok. So it's basically using `List<String>` as the type. And there must be some Scala magic in passing that; perhaps `ScalaObjectMapper` has overloaded method to get to `JavaType`.
I am just trying to figure out how to reproduce so I can measure effects of the change.

Now: given that it is not certain a change would be merge in 2.7, it may make sense for you to concurrently consider a change to explicitly avoid dynamic type resolution. There are at least two ways to do this:
1. Construct `JavaType` out of `List<String>`, pass `JavaType` (which is fully resolved)
2. Construct `ObjectReader` using `mapper.readerFor(type)`, where type is resolved and deserializer also resolved -- this will be slightly faster than going via `mapper.readValue()`

this assumes that type is known statically. Either approach is likely to result in performance improvement over baseline since even with caching there is some overhead from type resolution of root value type.

I'll see if I can figure out easy testing for performance aspects via `jackson-benchmarks` as I'd like to see how much cache can help; there are some parts of resolution that would still occur even with caching.

For what it's worth, it does look like caching along suggested lines works and improves performance as expected. There's still cost to resolution as lookup can only be made with resolved parameter types, but difference to optimal is lower with modified caching, key.

Ah. One more thought here: I think Scala module uses `TypeModifier`, and perhaps that has been implemented particularly inefficiently: it gets called once per resolution into `JavaType`.

.... and brief grepping shows that Scala module adds one modifier per type. Ugh. That is VERY inefficient as that would seem to create long linear call chains, without much actual benefit. It seems unlikely that users really benefit from composing modules serializer by serializer; but supporting this modularity adds all kinds of inefficiencies.

So I am guessing that 40x may actually occur with Scala, and caching in many ways works around Scala module issues more than specific cost of basic type resolution.

This doesn't mean that caching couldn't be added, but I think I better file an issue for Scala module (I don't maintain it) to address other issues.

issue.title: Performance problem with use of one `TypeModifier` for each registered Scala type (due to modularity)

repository.name: jackson-module-scala
repository.description: Add-on module for Jackson (https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson) to support Scala-specific datatypes

issue.body:
It looks like extreme modularity of Scala module may have nasty performance consequences, as per

https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-databind/issues/1277

at least wrt use of separate `TypeModifier` instances. Jackson `TypeFactory` calls linearly each and every modifier that is registered, assumption being there are typically from zero to one or maybe two modifiers, ever; and for things like Scala module to provide a single modifier that knows what kind of work is needed.

So: it would be good to see if there is a way to improve this situation, by combining all/most modifiers into one or a small number of separate modifiers. It is also worth checking whether all functionality is needed: usually only "collection-like" and "map-like" resolution is needed, and perhaps something for `Option` (to get `ReferenceType`). So perhaps some modifiers are not needed now (but may have been earlier).

body: I added caching of generic types as suggested (with slightly different impl); while it may be masking another problem improvement may make sense nonetheless. Fixed in 2.7.6 and 2.8.0, to be released.

Hmmh. My concerns about caching seem to be (alas!) valid: Travis shows failures:

https://travis-ci.org/FasterXML/jackson-databind/jobs/141404620

which I can not replicate locally. But symptoms suggest that caching of resolved generic type is probably introducing unwanted handlers (`JavaType` can have up to 4 handlers associated type).
Oddly enough 2.7 branch is NOT failing, but I assume it all has to do with order of running tests.

I suspect problem has mostly to do with per-property annotations (like `@JsonDeserialize(using)`, `@JsonSerialize(using)` for value handler, `@JsonTypeInfo` for type handler), but I am not quite sure how those could be attached during type resolution itself -- there are mutators, so a new instance needs to be created.
But by adding checks to verify cached instances have no handlers, I can reproduce 2-3 failures for a full test run, locally, so there is a problem to fix regardless.

There are a few ways to try to tackle this;
1. Remove caching from generic types (although in theory this could also affect non-generic types, as handlers are associated via properties, it's just that problems much more likely with container types)
2. Try to see if sharing of global `TypeFactory` might be partially to blame (i.e. create new instance per ObjectMapper, even if no `TypeModifier` registered). Most likely this would just mask problems as it seems plausible
3. Prevent caching of types with handlers.

Approach (3) seems most sensible in general, although I am tempted to do (1) for 2.7; patch releases should try to minimize the risks, and this seems like something that could cause gnarly very hard to debug problems.

So I will probably do that: undo fix for 2.7, rewrite it for 2.8.

issue.title: Allow sub-classing of type cache in `TypeFactory`

repository.name: jackson-databind
repository.description: General data-binding package for Jackson (2.x): works on streaming API (core) implementation(s)

issue.body:
(note: offshoot of #1277)

It would be nice to be able to customize properties of type cache, mainly to possibly increase its default and/or maximum size. Since `TypeFactory` is not easy configure in general, nor is there much benefit to add all the plumbing in general (it's not meant as user-configurable part, in general) the best we can do is to allow passing of cache in constructor, to allow configuration-by-subclassing.
So let's do that; should be easy enough.

rename.to: Add caching of resolved generic types for `TypeFactory`

body:
Fixed for 2.8, no test failures. Increased max cache size to 200: prefer not to extend indefinitely because cache is global, and NOT tied to `ObjectMapper` instance (unlike almost every other entity).
However, sub-classing does allow passing differently configured `LRUMap`. Will also add `withCache()` for 2.8.

issue.title: Release 2.8.0

repository.name: jackson-module-scala
repository.description: Add-on module for Jackson (https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson) to support Scala-specific datatypes

issue.body: We need 2.8.0 release now as well.
